item.title: STALKER 2 Expedition Update (Patch 1.7) Notes‚ÄîNew Mode, Difficulty Level, Anomalies, and More
item.content:encoded:
GSC Game World has once again proven it‚Äôs dedicated to the ongoing support of STALKER 2: Heart of Chornobyl, released almost one year ago. The open-world, (almost) post-apocalyptic shooter turned heads when it dropped on November 20 last year, and in the most recent update pushed out by the team, it has evolved once again.

The latest update, ‚ÄòExpedition‚Äô, introduces hundreds of bug fixes and stacks of new additions, improvements, and upgrades across the board, impacting everything from AI and controller handling to UI and player character behavior.

STALKER 2 Patch 1.7 Notes

STALKER 2 is set to be released on PlayStation 5 on November 20, which is probably why GSC Game World has issued such a massive update to the game in the 1.7 patch.

The team has boosted A-Life, the in-game AI system, to allow for territory control mechanics and faction battles. There‚Äôs a new ‚ÄòMaster‚Äô difficulty rating, as well as an Expedition Mode that offers a new level of immersion. When paired with the new ‚ÄòImmersive Mode‚Äô that serves as a replacement for a traditional photo mode, things get seriously engaging.

NPC vision and combat mechanics have had a major overhaul, making stealth more viable, and the game‚Äôs UI has been upgraded to make certain stats easier to understand. Skif, the player character, can adopt new ‚Äòconditions‚Äô based on the consumption of certain drinks, and two new anomalies pose threats in the game‚Äôs open world.

Controller players have had their aim assist features buffed, DualSense support has been added (of course), and, as I mentioned, hundreds of bug fixes have been applied.

Here they are.

All Fixes in STALKER 2 Patch 1.7

AI, Combat, and Mutants

The 22-year-old French player has enjoyed a rapid rise to fame in the Halo space, but now that Halo Infinite‚Äôs esports structure has all but finished, he‚Äôs ready to make that all-important move.

The all-new Surge roster was uncovered hours ago, and it contains mostly young and fresh players keen on cutting their teeth in the Call of Duty League this coming season.

Last season, Vancouver Surge had a stunning run, but couldn‚Äôt close out a tournament. The team wound up in second place numerous times, including at the Call of Duty League Championship in Canada, falling in second against a dominant OpTic Texas.

item.title: Rebecca Heineman, Co-Founder of Interplay, Has Passed Away
item.content:encoded:
Yesterday, the unfortunate news broke that Rebecca Heineman, co-founder of Interplay, Logicware, Contraband Entertainment, and Olde Sk√º√ºl, and the first national United States esports champion, had passed away. Following a battle with aggressive lung cancer, Heineman was recently hospitalized and given days to live.

As a pioneer in the games industry for women in development, video game archival, and lifetime creator of some of the most influential video games, Heineman leaves behind a stunning legacy.

Generational Run

In 1980, Rebecca Heineman traveled to Los Angeles to attend an enormous Space Invaders championship event, hosted on the Atari 2600. Not expecting to get anywhere close to the top spot, Heinemen unexpectedly won the entire event, going on to later win a second championship in New York.

That made Heineman the United States‚Äô first national esports champion.

As young as 16, Heineman was diving deep into coding, creating games and software at a time when concepts were just being framed. She co-founded Interplay Productions in 1983, a legendary studio that would go on to create Baldur‚Äôs Gate, The Bard‚Äôs Tale, Wasteland, and, probably most importantly, Fallout.

Heineman was rumored to be one of the last people in possession of the source code for the original Fallout game, released in 1997.

Her career took her through some of the most prolific companies in gaming, from Electronic Arts and Ubisoft to Microsoft and Sony, and she was a stalwart advocate for LGBTQ+ representation in the industry.

In a post on a GoFundMe page set up to help with medical costs, Heineman explained her story:

How did this start? I noticed when I was at PAX prime that I was out of breath climbing a single flight of stairs. When I got back to Dallas, I went to the emergency room and they found I had 2300ml of fluid in my lung cavity (see photos). They drained another 1600ml a week later. After cat scans, X-rays, and blood tests they finally found that the cancer is in my lungs and liver.

Yesterday, a final post was shared, along with a last image:

It‚Äôs time. According to my doctors. All further treatments are pointless. So, please donate so my kids can create a funeral worthy of my keyboard, Pixelbreaker! So I can make a worthy entrance for reuniting with my one true love, Jennell Jaquays.

Heineman, who predominantly went by the nickname ‚ÄòBurger‚Äô for two decades, leaves behind five children.

item.title: Take-Two CEO Says Gaming ‚Äòis Moving Towards PCs‚Äô
item.content:encoded:
In an interview with CNBC, Take-Two CEO Strauss Zelnick had some comments regarding the console/PC debate. In fact, it seems he‚Äôs taken a side in the whole debacle.

The divide between PC and console gaming has been a rather long one. Exclusives on one, better quality on the other, it all seems to go back and forth. Take-Two, known for publishing the Grand Theft Auto and NBA 2K, has been on both fronts. Every month, it seems the company finds itself on the best-selling list for consoles for its catalog of sports games. While it‚Äôll take a while for the company to see a bigger pay day with Grand Theft Auto 6 delayed, it seems the CEO has some thoughts on the console/PC divide.

Zelnick Says ‚ÄúBusiness is Moving Towards Open‚Äù to PC in Recent Interview

Take-Two CEO Strauss Zelnick sat down with CNBC‚Äôs Squawk Box for an interview on gaming. While on the topic of console gaming, Zelnick stated,

‚ÄúI think it‚Äôs moving towards PC and business is moving towards open rather than closed,‚Äù says Zelnick. ‚ÄúBut if you define console as the property, not the system, then the notion of a very rich game that you engage in for many hours that you play on a big screen ‚Äî that‚Äôs never going away.‚Äù

His comments do come at a convenient time, as Valve announced the upcoming console, the Steam Machine, which can play Steam games on your TV. Similarly, Xbox and Microsoft have veered a bit towards PC gamers, as recent statements from figures in the company indicate a change in tone from consoles. Weirdly, Take-Two‚Äôs biggest upcoming release, Grand Theft Auto 6, has not been announced for PC. Its last entry, Grand Theft Auto 5, didn‚Äôt see a PC release until two years after launching in 2013. In any case, it seems the company may be gearing to open up with PC gaming more than ever.
